title: The Boatbuilder
description: Your grandfather's last fishing boat. A Japanese collector wants to buy it.

scenes.title: The Offer
scenes.content:
The Japanese man wears pressed khakis and boat shoes that have never touched barnacles. He stands beside Abuelo's last panga, running manicured fingers along the cedar hull.

"Exquisite joinery," he says in careful English. "Traditional mortise and tenon. No screws in the frame at all."

You know this boat. Helped sand her ribs when you were twelve. Watched Abuelo fit each plank with his ancient adze, shaving curls so thin they caught sunlight.

"Forty thousand dollars," the collector continues. "Cash. I have a container ship waiting in Colón."

Forty thousand would fix the workshop roof. Pay off the loan on your own boat. Send Esperanza to university in Panama City like she wants.

Abuelo sits in his wicker chair, watching frigate birds circle the mangroves. His hearing isn't what it was, but his Spanish is perfect when he wants to ignore someone.

"She's not for sale," he says without looking over.

The collector turns to you. "Perhaps we could discuss this privately?"

Your daughter Esperanza appears at the workshop door, textbook in hand. She's been listening.

choices.text: Tell the collector you need time to think

scenes.title: Time to Think
scenes.content:
"Give us a week," you tell the collector.

He nods, hands you a business card. "I'll be at the Hotel Bocas. The offer stands until Friday."

After his water taxi disappears around the point, Abuelo spits into the water.

"Time to think about what? Some things aren't for sale."

"Forty thousand, Abuelo. You know what that means."

"I know what it means." He struggles to his feet. "Means you think everything has a price."

That evening, you find Esperanza at the old dock, reading by lamplight. Mosquitoes circle her head but she doesn't notice.

"Advanced calculus," she says when you sit down. "For the engineering entrance exam."

"The university money..."

"I heard." She closes the book. "Papá, why did Abuelo build that boat?"

You remember the stories. How he worked two years without pay after Hurricane Mitch destroyed his tools. How he carved the transom during your grandmother's funeral, needing something to do with his hands.

"He built it for himself. After the fishing got bad. Said he needed to remember what he was good at."

choices.text: Ask Esperanza if she wants you to sell it
Tell her about your grandfather's sacrifices
Suggest finding another way to pay for university

scenes.title: Daughter's Voice
scenes.content:
"Esperanza, ven acá."

She walks over, still clutching her calculus book. The collector watches with interest.

"What do you think about this man's offer?"

She looks at the boat. At her great-grandfather. At the calculator sticking out of her backpack.

"I think," she says slowly, "that Abuelo never built boats to sell them."

The collector shifts on his expensive shoes. "Miss, this boat would be preserved. Displayed properly. People would understand its cultural significance."

"In Japan?"

"In my private collection, yes."

Esperanza runs her hand along the gunwale where Abuelo carved his initials and the date. "Papá, you remember when the red snapper disappeared? When the shrimp boats came?"

You remember. The village fleet dwindled from thirty pangas to eight in two years.

"Abuelo didn't sell his tools then either," she continues. "Even when Mama got sick. Even when we had nothing."

The collector clears his throat. "I could go to forty-five thousand."

Abuelo laughs. It's not a pleasant sound.

choices.text: Tell him you'll consider the higher offer

scenes.title: Standing with Tradition
scenes.content:
"You heard him. She's not for sale."

The collector's smile doesn't waver. "I understand. Family attachment. But consider the reality. How many traditional boatbuilders are left in Bocas? Three? Four?"

"More than that."

"Who still use the old methods? No power tools, no modern adhesives?"

You can't answer. He's right. Even you use fiberglass now for repairs.

"Your grandfather is eighty-seven. His knowledge dies with him unless it's preserved properly."

Abuelo stands up slowly. "Mijo, tell this man something for me."

You translate as he speaks: "He says his knowledge doesn't live in museums. It lives in working boats. In hands that know wood."

The collector nods respectfully. "But who will learn? Your daughter wants to be an engineer. Your son moved to Panama City."

The words hit harder than they should. Miguel hasn't touched a plane in five years. Esperanza can solve differential equations but can't tell cedar from mahogany.

"The offer remains open," the collector says, walking toward his water taxi. "Cultural preservation requires difficult choices sometimes."

choices.text: Ask Abuelo to teach Esperanza the craft

scenes.title: The Choice Offered
scenes.content:
"If I sold it, you could go to university. Study engineering like you want. What would you choose?"

Esperanza doesn't answer right away. She picks up a wood shaving from the dock, rolls it between her fingers.

"You know what I learned in calculus? About optimization problems. Finding maximum value under constraints."

"This isn't math, mija."

"Isn't it?" She holds up the shaving. "Abuelo taught me this is cedro espinoso. Takes forty years to grow straight enough for planking. The tree that became this boat was older than he is."

A pelican dives near the dock. Comes up empty.

"The constraint isn't money, Papá. It's time. How long before there's nobody left who knows why that grain pattern matters? Why those joints hold when screws would fail?"

You built boats for twenty years before you understood what she just said.

"So you don't want to go to university?"

"I want to go. But I want these boats to still exist when I come back."

In the distance, a water taxi heads toward the village. The collector, returning for an answer.

scenes.title: Old Stories
scenes.content:
You tell her about Hurricane Mitch. How the storm surge took every boat except the ones hauled highest into the mangroves. How Abuelo walked the tideline for weeks, collecting bronze screws and galvanized bolts from the wreckage.

"He sorted every piece of hardware. Straightened bent nails with a hammer. Said waste was a sin when people needed boats to eat."

Esperanza listens without interrupting. This is history she's heard fragments of, never the whole story.

"The insurance money never came. The government promised new boats, then forgot about us. So Abuelo started over. Seventy-three years old, cutting trees with a hand saw."

You point to the boat floating beside the dock. "Every plank in that hull came from trees he selected himself. Walked the forest for months, looking for the right grain, the right color."

"Why that boat, though? Why not sell one of the others?"

"Because he built it for himself. Not for fishing. Not for selling. For remembering what his hands could do."

Esperanza opens her textbook again, but doesn't read. "Forty thousand would pay for a lot of remembering."

She's right. It would also erase it.

choices.text: Decide the stories matter more than money
Ask what Abuelo would want you to do

scenes.title: The Real Question
scenes.content:
"What do you think Abuelo really wants?"

Esperanza closes her book. "I think he wants to know his work mattered. That it won't disappear."

You walk back to the workshop together. Abuelo sits in his chair, watching the tide come in. The collector's boat is gone, but his business card lies on the workbench.

"Abuelo," Esperanza says in Spanish, "teach me to read wood grain."

He looks up, surprised.

"The engineering program has summer breaks. Three months every year."

Abuelo struggles to his feet, walks to a stack of cedar planks. He runs his finger along one edge, showing her the tight rings near the heartwood.

"This piece," he says, "would split in heavy weather. See how the grain runs out here?"

Esperanza nods, traces the same line with her finger.

"But this one." He selects another plank. "Straight grain, no knots. This one bends without breaking."

You pick up the collector's card, tear it in half. Forty thousand dollars becomes confetti on the workshop floor.

Some knowledge is worth more than money. Some boats are built to stay home.

scenes.title: Stories Over Money
scenes.content:
"The stories stay with the boat. Sell it, and they're just words."

Esperanza nods. "Like a song without music."

The next morning, you find the collector waiting at the dock. His pressed khakis are identical to yesterday's.

"Have you reconsidered?"

"We have." You hand him back his business card. "She stays here."

He sighs, but doesn't seem surprised. "I respect your decision. Though I think you're making a mistake."

"Maybe. But it's our mistake to make."

After he leaves, Abuelo comes down to the water. He climbs into his boat carefully, settles onto the center thwart.

"Take her out," he says. "Been too long."

You start the small outboard, steer toward the channel. The boat moves like she remembers what she was built for. Smooth and steady, cutting clean through the chop.

Abuelo trails his hand in the water. "Forty years I've been building boats. This is the first one I kept."

"Why?"

"Because I finally built one I was proud of."

The mangroves close around you, green and eternal. Some things are worth keeping.
